The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 introduces penalties of up to 25 years imprisonment for securities fraud involving false pretenses or fraudulent schemes related to securities transactions. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 introduces penalties for securities fraud, including tampering with records or impeding official proceedings, with fines or imprisonment up to 20 years. Amendments to the Federal Sentencing Guidelines are also made. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 requests the United States Sentencing Commission to promptly review sentencing guidelines for securities fraud, consider enhancements for corporate officers committing fraud, and submit policy recommendations to Congress. The Sentencing Commission is asked to ensure guidelines reflect the seriousness of securities offenses. The Sentencing Commission is requested to review sentencing guidelines for securities fraud, ensuring seriousness is reflected and considering enhancements for corporate officers committing fraud. They should also ensure consistency with other directives, account for circumstances justifying exceptions, and adequacy of offense levels for obstruction of justice cases. The Sentencing Commission is requested to review and enhance guidelines for securities fraud, obstruction of justice, and fraud offenses with over 50 victims. They must make necessary changes to ensure consistency and adequacy in sentencing guidelines within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The United States Sentencing Commission is requested to promptly create guidelines or amendments related to securities fraud, obstruction of justice, and fraud offenses with over 50 victims within 120 days of the Act's enactment. This should be done in accordance with the procedures outlined in the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987. SEC. 5. DEBTS NONDISCHARGEABLE IF INCURRED IN VIOLATION OF SECURITIES FRAUD LAWS. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include claims for violation of securities laws or common law fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of securities as non-dischargeable debts. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes claims for violation of securities laws or common law fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of securities as non-dischargeable debts. This amendment covers manipulation in connection with securities transactions and the results of legal actions such as judgments, settlements, fines, penalties, and restitution payments. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a new section requiring corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. Failure to comply with this certification can result in criminal penalties of fines up to $5,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years. The new section in Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code imposes criminal penalties for violations, with fines up to $5,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years for willful violations. SEC. 7 introduces penalties for attempts and conspiracies to commit offenses against the United States, with the same penalties as the intended offense. SEC. 8 increases criminal penalties under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, raising fines to $5,000,000 and imprisonment to 20 years. Section 32(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to increase fines to $5,000,000 and imprisonment to 20 years. Additionally, the freeze authority for the Securities and Exchange Commission is temporarily expanded. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to allow the Securities and Exchange Commission to petition for a temporary freeze on extraordinary payments by issuers under investigation for securities law violations. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment allows the SEC to petition for a temporary freeze on issuer payments under investigation, subject to court supervision for 45 days. The temporary order requires notice and a hearing unless impracticable or against public interest. The order becomes effective immediately and can only be set aside, limited, or suspended by a competent court. The order issued under clause (i) becomes effective immediately, served upon parties subject to it, and remains enforceable for 45 days unless set aside by a court. Extensions can be granted for up to 45 additional days, not exceeding a total of 90 days, upon showing good cause. Process for violations charged against the issuer or other parties is outlined in the amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The temporary order issued under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 can remain in effect for up to 90 days if the issuer or other party is charged with violations during that period. If no violations are charged, the order can be reviewed by the court. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows for a temporary order to be issued for up to 90 days if violations are charged. If no violations are charged, the order can be reviewed by the court. Additionally, a technical amendment was made to Section 21C(c)(2) of the Act. SEC. 10. AUTHORITY OF THE COMMISSION TO PROHIBIT PERSONS FROM SERVING AS OFFICERS OR DIRECTORS. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 empower the Commission to prohibit individuals who have violated certain regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. This authority allows the Commission to issue orders prohibiting such individuals from holding these positions permanently or for a specified period. The Securities Act of 1933 allows the Commission to prohibit individuals who have violated regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Commission may issue orders to prohibit such individuals permanently or for a specified period. SEC. 11. RETALIATION AGAINST INFORMANT. Amends Section 1513 of title 18, United States Code to penalize retaliation against informants providing truthful information to law enforcement regarding Federal offenses. Penalties include fines or imprisonment up to 10 years.
